context: [4] (B) The calculated OH reactivity (solid black squares) consists of contributions from OH reactions with isoprene (open orange squares), CO and NO2 (green diamonds), HCHO (black plus symbols), acetaldehyde (magenta circles), anthropogenic VOCs (red triangles), and terpenes (blue crosses). [5] The data are smoothed with a running mean over 5 K, which smoothes the curves without changing the statistics of the missing OH reactivity. [1] We used the chemical species reported in Table 1 to calculate the OH reactivity for PROPHET (Fig. 1B). [2] Isoprene provides the largest contribution (49%), with contributions from CO and NO2 (21%), HCHO and acetaldehyde (12% each), anthropogenic VOCs (3%), monoterpenes (2%), and O3, HO2, SO2, and NO (<1% combined). [3] At temperatures less than 288 K, only CO and NO2 contributed significantly to the OH reactivity. [4] BVOCs contribute less at these temperatures, because their concentrations are below the instruments' detection limits . [1] The difference between measured and calculated OH reactivity is temperature-dependent (Fig. 2).

llm_generation.summary: In this context, 2-methylbuta-1,3-diene (isoprene) and acetaldehyde are both mentioned as contributors to hydroxyl (OH) reactivity in the atmosphere. The data indicates that acetaldehyde contributes 12% to the overall OH reactivity, similar to formaldehyde (HCHO). While both compounds are part of the broader discussion on volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and their reactivity, there is no direct interaction or specific relationship detailed between them beyond their contributions to OH reactivity.
